text: Bifurcated Delta Mercury Control Program
label: HH1

text: Introduction
label: HH1

text: The purpose of this document is to provide a focused description of a possible
label: TITLE

text: “bifurcated” structure of the Delta Methylmercury (MeHg) Total Maximum Daily Load
label: BODY

text: (TMDL) process (Delta TMDL).  It presents:
label: BODY

text: • A general description of a bifurcated TMDL process,
label: BODY

text: • A Southern California example of a bifurcated TMDL process,
label: BODY

text: • A preliminary “vision” of the Delta TMDL including,
label: BODY

text: • The proposed study area, and
label: BODY

text: • The specific bifurcated approach for the Delta.
label: BODY

text: • Anticipated near-term requirements of, and implications to MeHg producers and
label: BODY

text: dischargers,
label: BODY

text: • Potential long-term approaches to review and revise the Delta MeHg TMDL.
label: BODY

text: The Bifurcated TMDL Model
label: HH1

text: In late 2008 and early 2009, various Delta stakeholders met to discuss the feasibility of
label: BODY

text: restructuring the Basin Plan amendment to provide for a more adaptive approach to
label: BODY

text: establishing a Delta TMDL by October 2009.  A bifurcated approach has been
label: BODY

text: implemented in other parts of the State where TMDLs need to be developed quickly and
label: BODY

text: there are information gaps or complicated regulatory options that would benefit from
label: BODY

text: further detailed discussions.  The basic model is to establish the technical parts of the
label: BODY

text: TMDL and an adaptive implementation approach that allows for future revisions of the
label: BODY

text: TMDL as data becomes available and water quality improvements occur.  The
label: BODY

text: bifurcated approach recognizes that more information needs to be collected to:
label: HH1

text: • Confirm initial allocations and,
label: BODY

text: • Evaluate actions that can be implemented to meet allocations.
label: BODY

text: The bifurcated approach sets up the framework for making certain the appropriate
label: BODY

text: information is collected and the appropriate dialogue takes place with affected
label: BODY

text: stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: EXAMPLE – Calleguas Creek Nitrogen TMDL
label: BODY

text: The Calleguas Creek Nitrogen TMDL adopted by the Los Angeles Regional
label: BODY

text: Board includes a numeric target, waste load allocations for wastewater treatment
label: BODY

text: plants and load allocations for agriculture and other nonpoint sources that would
label: BODY

text: need to be achieved within a time schedule.  In addition, the TMDL set interim
label: BODY

text: limits for wastewater treatment plants that would apply in 4 years.  A Nonpoint
label: BODY

text: Source BMP evaluation committee was formed and an existing stakeholder
label: BODY

text: committee agreed to take on the responsibility for developing and implementing
label: BODY

text: a monitoring program.  A study work plan was due from the stakeholder group in
label: BODY

text: 1 year and the TMDL spelled out minimum monitoring requirements.  The TMDL
label: BODY

text: indicated that if this stakeholder process failed to produce the specified reports,
label: BODY

text: the Regional Board would consider requiring dischargers to implement
label: BODY

text: monitoring and special studies.
label: BODY

text: Delta Mercury TMDL
label: HH1

text: Consistent with longstanding commitments by the Regional Board to USEPA, the goal
label: BODY

text: of the Board’s Executive Officer is to deliver the Delta TMDL for Board approval by
label: BODY

text: October 2009.  The bifurcated approach would be used to address the unique
label: BODY

text: hydrologic and geographic differences of the Delta and its tributary conditions.  To apply
label: BODY

text: this bifurcated approach to the TMDL and successfully achieve the target date, Board
label: BODY

text: staff and stakeholders need to define the technical aspects of the TMDL (Technical
label: BODY

text: TMDL) and they need to prepare an Implementation Framework (Framework), both
label: HH1

text: described below.  Attachment A presents a general description of the items to be
label: BODY

text: included in a Basin Plan amendment.
label: BODY

text: Proposed TMDL Project Area
label: BODY

text: The proposed allocation approach is to organize the Delta into seven subareas rather
label: BODY

text: than one massive geographic area.  These subareas have been proposed based on
label: BODY

text: watershed boundaries and existing data on water flows and mercury sources.  Each
label: BODY

text: subarea has different variables to be considered such as:
label: BODY

text: Land uses,
label: BODY

text: Discharger occurrence and distribution, and
label: BODY

text: Tributary sizes and sources
label: BODY

text: For example, in the Sacramento River subarea, fish tissue mercury concentrations are
label: BODY

text: 60% higher than Board staff’s proposed fish tissue objective.  To reduce the fish tissue
label: BODY

text: concentration by 60%, current scientific research indicates that there needs to be a 60%
label: BODY

text: reduction in the concentration of MeHg in the Sacramento River.  Since the Board does
label: BODY

text: not currently have sufficient information on which sources have the best potential for
label: BODY

text: reducing their loads of MeHg, Board staff proposes to assign a 60% reduction in MeHg
label: BODY

text: to apply to all dischargers in the Sacramento River subarea, including the tributary
label: BODY

text: sources, except those dischargers with very low discharge MeHg concentrations.
label: BODY

text: Allocations would be assigned to:
label: BODY

text: • Wastewater treatment plants and urban areas (NPDES permitted facilities and
label: BODY

text: municipal service areas),
label: BODY

text: • Managed wetland areas,
label: BODY

text: • Irrigated agricultural areas and
label: BODY

text: • Instream production (assigned to State and/or Federal agencies) for within Delta
label: BODY

text: sources.
label: BODY

text: In essence, each subarea will be treated as a separate TMDL with each having distinct
label: BODY

text: allocations that are consistent with the unique conditions of that subarea.  Additionally,
label: BODY

text: the watersheds upstream of each Delta subarea would be assigned the same reduction
label: BODY

text: required for the downstream subarea.  Board staff expects that similar discharger
label: BODY

text: categories are present in the upstream areas as those identified in the Delta.  Additional
label: BODY

text: categories include upstream mines and dredge fields, unmanaged open space areas
label: BODY

text: (e.g., forests and other native upland areas), and reservoir releases.
label: BODY

text: Technical TMDL Components
label: BODY

text: At this time, Board staff and scientific peer reviewers believe there is sufficient scientific
label: BODY

text: rationale supporting the:
label: BODY

text: • Proposed fish tissue objectives;
label: BODY

text: • Linkage between MeHg in the fish and MeHg in water; and the
label: BODY

text: • General identification of sources.
label: BODY

text: If all MeHg sources can be reduced by the amounts suggested in the draft TMDL,
label: BODY

text: current research suggests that the fish tissue objectives can be met.  However, the
label: BODY

text: main issue with the proposed mercury control program is whether the various sources
label: BODY

text: identified in the TMDL can achieve the allocations by implementing feasible
label: BODY

text: methylmercury and total mercury control actions.  At this time, there is information that
label: BODY

text: suggests some source categories can reduce MeHg loading, but there is much
label: BODY

text: information that needs to be collected for other sources.  To comply with State and
label: BODY

text: Federal requirements, the Technical TMDL should include the following:
label: BODY

text: • Fish tissue objectives,
label: BODY

text: • Load and waste load allocations,
label: BODY

text: • Margin of safety, and
label: BODY

text: • An Implementation Framework.
label: BODY

text: Adaptive Implementation Framework
label: BODY

text: As stated above, the Technical TMDL will include allocations on a subarea-specific
label: BODY

text: basis for the Delta.  Over time, these allocations may be revised based on additional
label: BODY

text: data.  Additional information will be needed to determine if the allocations are
label: BODY

text: appropriate and achievable or if the allocations for fish tissue objectives need to be
label: BODY

text: changed.  To support an atmosphere of learning and change (when appropriate), the
label: BODY

text: Basin Plan amendment will include an adaptive approach to study MeHg sources and
label: BODY

text: potential control methods, assess Delta conditions, and propose long-range revisions
label: BODY

text: and solutions.
label: BODY

text: The proposal is to have a two-phased approach for the Delta mercury control program.
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 would last about 8 years.  The first 7 years would consist of a study period to
label: BODY

text: gather more information about methylmercury production and to develop management
label: BODY

text: practices.  During the 8th year, staff would revise the TMDL based on the Phase 1 study
label: BODY

text: results.  Phase 2 would include implementation of feasible management practices
label: BODY

text: developed in Phase 1.
label: BODY

text: The first step towards creating a long-range adaptive implementation approach is to
label: BODY

text: prepare an Adaptive Implementation Framework (Framework) for the Basin Plan
label: BODY

text: amendment.  The Framework should describe the process that will be implemented
label: BODY

text: over the next several years so there is sufficient information for the Board to reevaluate
label: BODY

text: the allocations and implementation plan in 8 years.  The Framework should be very
label: BODY

text: clear so that dischargers and the regulated community know what actions need to be
label: BODY

text: initiated and what information needs to be collected during the 7-year study period.  The
label: BODY

text: Framework should describe as best as possible, the process that will be implemented to
label: BODY

text: meet the adaptive implementation goals of the TMDL.  However, the Framework needs
label: BODY

text: to be flexible enough so that efforts can be adapted as new information becomes
label: BODY

text: available.  The Framework must propose future approaches that are reasonable and
label: BODY

text: equitable.
label: BODY

text: Components of the Proposed Framework
label: BODY

text: Dischargers would work with the Board to develop a comprehensive implementation
label: BODY

text: Framework and to implement studies.  We need to develop a detailed plan at the
label: BODY

text: beginning of Phase 1 that describes how the 7-year stakeholder process should be set
label: BODY

text: up and implemented and exactly what is required from stakeholders.  The Framework
label: BODY

text: should provide some protection and incentives for working with the Board to complete
label: BODY

text: studies.
label: BODY

text: What should be included in the Framework?  It could include but not be limited to the
label: BODY

text: following elements:
label: BODY

text: • Sufficient direction to ensure that a comprehensive, scientifically defensible,
label: BODY

text: implementation program can be developed in 8 years.  It should clearly describe
label: BODY

text: the general information that needs to be collected (e.g., MeHg and inorganic
label: BODY

text: mercury reduction studies and development of control plans) and describe the
label: BODY

text: process that will be implemented to gather and evaluate the information.  Board
label: BODY

text: staff currently recommends that all discharger types both within and upstream of
label: BODY

text: the Delta should participate in developing information and designing and
label: BODY

text: implementing studies.
label: BODY

text: • Regional Board commitment to work with the State and Federal governments to
label: BODY

text: develop an implementation plan to address instream methylmercury production
label: BODY

text: both within the Delta and in tributaries.
label: BODY

text: • Interim requirements for NPDES wastewater treatment plant dischargers to
label: BODY

text: ensure that the mercury problem does not get worse during the study period.
label: BODY

text: The Board staff’s current recommendation is to include narrative interim limits in
label: BODY

text: the Basin Plan amendment for NPDES permittees and for them to implement
label: BODY

text: mercury minimization programs.  In addition, Board staff recommends that new
label: BODY

text: WWTP dischargers monitor their effluent for methylmercury and total mercury.
label: BODY

text: • Managers of proposed wetland restoration projects should consider the potential
label: BODY

text: MeHg enhancement from their projects and determine, in coordination with the
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 studies, if there are any feasible control measures that could be
label: BODY

text: implemented as the new projects are built.
label: BODY

text: • A plan for meeting the San Francisco Bay Water Board’s inorganic mercury
label: BODY

text: allocation.
label: BODY

text: • Specific MeHg and inorganic mercury reduction actions that should be initiated
label: BODY

text: during the 8-year Phase 1 period (i.e., Cache Creek Settling Basin improvements
label: BODY

text: and possibly other projects).  These could be projects to address known
label: BODY

text: substantial sources.
label: BODY

text: • Measures to reduce MeHg exposure for people eating contaminated fish.
label: BODY

text: • Regional Board commitment to develop TMDLs and control programs for Delta
label: BODY

text: tributaries during Phase 1, and
label: BODY

text: • General framework for an offset program.  The 2008 proposed Basin Plan
label: BODY

text: amendment includes this element.
label: BODY

text: Attachment A is a preliminary proposal for the Framework.  Board staff drafted this for
label: BODY

text: review and modification by the Framework stakeholder group that is being convened for
label: BODY

text: the first part of the bifurcated TMDL.
label: BODY

text: Requirements and Implications
label: HH1

text: Board staff anticipates that the adaptive approach will be used over the first seven years
label: BODY

text: of the Delta TMDL.  During that time, Board staff will focus on ensuring that MeHg
label: BODY

text: conditions do not deteriorate (to the extent feasible) and partnering with all stakeholders
label: BODY

text: to learn more about MeHg production, transport and exposure to humans and the
label: BODY

text: environment.
label: BODY

text: A key perspective by the Board staff is the following: No practices or process
label: HH1

text: changes would be required to be implemented toward meeting the allocations
label: HH1

text: during the Phase 1 study period.  The Board commits to reconsidering the TMDL,
label: HH1

text: allocations, compliance time schedule, and implementation plan in about 8 years and
label: BODY

text: would modify the Basin Plan as necessary based on new information.  Dischargers
label: BODY

text: would not be required to implement methylmercury reduction projects in Phase 1.  In
label: BODY

text: addition, the current Basin Plan amendment would not require dischargers to meet
label: BODY

text: allocations until 2030.  The Board may modify the compliance date at the end of
label: BODY

text: Phase 1 based on the results of the Phase 1 studies.  The Delta Mercury Control
label: BODY

text: Program Phase 2 would contain implementation requirements, allocations, and a
label: BODY

text: compliance time schedule.  In the absence of the Phase 1 studies, the allocations and
label: BODY

text: 2030 compliance date would not change.
label: BODY

text: What applies to dischargers during the 7-year study period?
label: BODY

text: • Dischargers in impaired Delta subareas and in tributary watersheds could
label: BODY

text: collaborate on the methylmercury studies.  The purpose of the studies is to
label: BODY

text: develop methods to reduce MeHg from various source types and identify MeHg
label: BODY

text: and total mercury sources that can be feasibly controlled.  Feasible control
label: BODY

text: methods may address direct MeHg inputs from external sources such as drains
label: BODY

text: from irrigated agricultural and wetlands, urban runoff, wastewater treatment plant
label: BODY

text: effluent, erosion from dredge fields, and mine site discharges, as well as MeHg
label: BODY

text: inputs from within-channel sources such as open-water and wetland sediments.
label: BODY

text: • Stakeholders could work together to determine how to most quickly and
label: BODY

text: effectively accomplish MeHg and total mercury source reductions to achieve the
label: BODY

text: fish tissue objectives.  The stakeholder group(s) also could work on a plan to
label: BODY

text: prioritize methylmercury and inorganic mercury control actions within the
label: BODY

text: watersheds.
label: BODY

text: • NPDES dischargers would be required to maintain performance-based effluent
label: BODY

text: limits during the 7-year study period.  Staff needs to work with USEPA and the
label: BODY

text: dischargers on the Basin Plan language for this.
label: BODY

text: • New managed wetland projects should work with the other stakeholders and
label: BODY

text: evaluate management practices that could be implemented to minimize MeHg
label: BODY

text: production, and implement any reasonable practices.
label: BODY

text: • Dischargers can apply directly to the Board to implement offset projects and the
label: BODY

text: Board would determine the amount of credit that would be accrued.
label: BODY

text: What applies to dischargers after the end of the study phase?
label: BODY

text: After the study phase, the Regional Board is required to reevaluate the TMDL
label: BODY

text: allocations and time line, based on study results.  At that time, the Regional Board will
label: BODY

text: determine what requirements will apply.  In the absence of the studies, the Board will
label: BODY

text: have limited information on which make modifications to the original allocations and
label: BODY

text: compliance schedule.
label: BODY
